0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-putin-trump-idUSKBN1352J9	Trump's foreign policy approach almost same as that of Putin: Kremlin	"
By Andrew Osborn
| MOSCOW
MOSCOW The Kremlin said on Thursday U.S. President-elect Donald Trump's foreign policy approach was ""phenomenally close"" to that of President Vladimir Putin
column2: giving Russia hope that tattered U.S.-Russia relations could gradually be improved.Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov
column3: speaking in New York
column4: said he saw incredible similarities between the two men's foreign policy ideas
column5: and this meant there was a solid basis to start a meaningful dialogue between Moscow and Washington.         Peskov
column6: in the United States for a chess tournament
column7: said he was struck by how similar parts of Trump's victory speech were to a speech Putin gave in southern Russia last month. Both men said they would put their own country's national interests first
column8: but that they would be ready to develop ties with other nations
column9: depending on how ready other countries were to deepen relations themselves.

column1: They (Putin and Trump) set out the same main foreign policy principles and that is incredible
column2: Peskov said in comments broadcast by Russian state TV's Channel One on Thursday evening.""It is phenomenal how close they are to one another when it comes to their conceptual approach to foreign policy. And that is probably a good basis for our moderate optimism that they will at least be able to start a dialogue to start to clear out the Augean stables in our bilateral relations.""

column1: With Moscow and Washington now at odds over Syria
column2: Ukraine and NATO
column3: Peskov cautioned that it would take a long time before relations could return to a high level
column4: however
column5: because of how far they had been allowed to deteriorate.""An atmosphere of mutual trust takes years to achieve
column6: he said. ""It's not possible to just declare that there is an atmosphere of mutual trust
column7: especially after such serious damage was done in the last few years to our relations.""

column1: Peskov told the TASS news agency separately that Putin was ready to be flexible when it came to mending ties which he wanted to improve
column2: but that there was a limit to his flexibility and that he would need to see some U.S. reciprocity.Peskov spoke after one of Russia's most senior diplomats told the Interfax news agency earlier on Thursday that the Russian government had been in touch with members of Trump's political team during the U.S. election campaign and knew most of his entourage. (Editing by Mark Heinrich)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-business-idUSKBN1352GR	Trump's business empire poses unprecedented potential conflicts of interest	"
By Joseph Ax
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Donald Trump campaigned for president as a savvy billionaire who would apply his business acumen to improving the U.S. economy
column2: cutting taxes for Americans and negotiating better trade deals.But his vast
column3: complicated network of businesses under the Trump Organization
column4: including numerous foreign investments and debts
column5: could create unprecedented conflicts of interest when he takes the oath of office as U.S. president in January
column6: government ethics experts said. Federal law does not prohibit the president from being involved in private business while in office
column7: even though members of Congress and lower-ranking executive branch officials are subject to strict conflict-of-interest rules. Lyndon Johnson
column9: quietly managed his broadcasting businesses despite insisting publicly that he had ceased all involvement
column11: Robert Caro.""There are no legal restrictions
column14: the executive director of the nonpartisan watchdog Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington.But most presidents in recent decades have voluntarily placed their personal assets
column16: in blind trusts overseen by independent advisers to avoid any appearance of impropriety
column17: experts said. Under a blind trust
column18: the owner has no say or knowledge in how the assets are managed.President Barack Obama was one exception
column19: but his investments are mostly in broad-based index funds and U.S. Treasury notes with little chance of conflicts.Trump's businesses include licensing deals
column20: hotels and golf courses around the world. During the campaign
column21: he filed a 104-page financial disclosure statement
column23: that showed he had financial interests in more than 500 entities with names like China Trademark LLC and DT Marks Qatar LLC but had few details.BLIND TRUST

column1: While plenty of wealthy men have been president
column2: no one has ascended to the White House with such a complex array of assets.Trump's spokeswoman did not respond to a request for comment on how he planned to manage his businesses while he was in the White House.

column1: During the campaign
column2: Trump did say he would likely transfer day-to-day operations to his children. But experts in government ethics said that would do little to insulate Trump.""That presumably frees some time up for him to be the president
column3: but it doesn't do anything to clear the conflicts of interest
column4: said Kenneth Gross
column5: a Washington
column6: D.C.-based lawyer who has counseled high-ranking political appointees on ethics laws. ""His family's interests
column8: are co-existent with his own.""The nature of Trump's businesses
column10: makes a blind trust all but meaningless - even if he were inclined to shift control of his empire from his family
column11: an idea he has rejected.Gross advised Michael Bloomberg
column13: when he became mayor of New York City. Bloomberg stepped away from day-to-day operations at his data and media company
column15: and donated all terminals that were used by city agencies to avoid any impression of profiting from public funds.Some of the potential problems for the Republican president-elect are obvious. One of his latest ventures
column16: a luxury hotel in Washington just blocks from the White House
column17: leases its property from the U.S. government
column18: putting Trump on both sides of any landlord-tenant disputes.Others are more opaque. Trump has licensing deals and diverse real estate holdings in numerous countries that could benefit from foreign government subsidies or tax breaks. Companies in which he holds an interest owe hundreds of millions of dollars in debt to foreign banks that are subject to U.S. regulations
column19: such as Deutsche Bank and Bank of China
column20: according to the New York Times and the Wall Street Journal.

column1: His properties include hotels in countries like Turkey
column2: Uruguay
column3: the Philippines and South Korea
column4: and golf courses in the United Arab Emirates
column5: Ireland and Britain.  Conflicts of interest could stem
column6: for example
column7: from countries trying to influence policies by doing business with any of his companies or even his children. His daughter Ivanka has a line of fashion products
column8: which along with other Trump-branded items are made in countries like China.Trump has accused China of currency manipulation and threatened to put tariffs on its imports.GOVERNMENT REVIEW OF TRUMP INC. DEALS?

column1: Trump's opponent
column2: Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton
column3: faced criticism during the campaign over the Clinton Foundation
column4: the charity founded by her husband
column5: former President Bill Clinton.

column1: That was despite an ethics agreement that Hillary Clinton signed in 2009 in order to become Obama's secretary state that was designed to ensure donors could not sway U.S. foreign policy. Under the deal
column2: the State Department was allowed to review any new contributions from foreign governments.Unlike Clinton
column3: however
column4: Trump is not answerable to anyone else as president. And he has already shown himself willing to blur the lines between campaigning and marketing
column5: holding events at his own properties and touting his companies during speeches. Given the high-profile properties that bear his name
column6: a blind trust would do little to help his case
column7: experts said.""You can't put a golf course in a blind trust; it would be pointless
column9: a Washington lawyer and an expert on government ethics. ""The idea behind a blind trust is that it's blind - you don't know what assets are held.""The only unassailable solution
column11: would be for Trump to sell off his businesses and place the proceeds in a blind trust.With no legal requirements
column12: Trump's actions as president are only subject to the will of the voters or to built-in checks and balances like Congressional oversight. The potential for conflicts is exacerbated by the lack of publicly known details about Trump's holdings. Even his net worth is unclear. Trump has boasted of more than $10 billion in wealth
column13: but financial magazines have estimated his fortune at less than half that.He has refused to release his tax returns
column14: breaking with decades of presidential campaign tradition
column15: and legal experts said he is under no obligation to do so as president.His dealings with foreign governments are thus largely unknown. He will likely face scrutiny of policy decisions that affect countries where he is known to have business interests
column17: editing by Ross Colvin; Additional reporting by Mica Rosenberg)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-enthymemes-analysi-idUSKBN1352DJ	Investors
column2: economists brace for new dangerous game: parsing Trump's words	"

column1: By Jonathan Spicer
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Move over
column2: Janet Yellen. The Federal Reserve chief has a challenger for the title of speaker most scrutinized by Wall Street
column3: and it's Donald Trump. All new U.S. President-elects are closely monitored by the financial community for clues about what their policies mean for markets. But Trump's speaking style
column4: often using enthymemes or incomplete sentences that leave room for interpretation
column5: along with vague or contradictory campaign promises make him all the more challenging to decipher. ""His statements are crazy. He says peculiar things
column6: like building the wall and getting Mexico to pay for it
column7: that you know are just not going to happen
column9: a Fed historian and professor of political economy at Carnegie Mellon University
column10: in Pittsburg. ""But his actions as opposed to his statements have been very moderate
column11: he said.Exhibit A for how Trump has policy makers and investors hanging on his every word came shortly after the Republican's conciliatory acceptance speech early Wednesday. Bonds fell and stocks gained as investors placed tentative bets that Trump's somewhat vague platform of economic stimulus would translate into corporate profits and higher inflation.The stakes are high. With a Republican controlled House and Senate
column12: Trump has the opportunity to use his time in office to radically reshape the American economy. He has pledged dramatic tax cuts
column14: and wants to repeal Obamacare. These measures he says will turbo-charge growth and help boost the wages of those who have lost out in a globalized world where ""middle-class"" jobs have been squeezed.With the U.S. budget deficit at just 3.2 percent of gross domestic product
column16: and near record low interest rates
column17: Trump has room to undertake a large-scale fiscal boost
column18: at least in the short term. His restrained acceptance speech hinted that infrastructure was a priority. Trump said he would ""rebuild our highways

column1: On the campaign trail
column2: Trump's speeches were full of superlatives and unfinished thoughts that only complicated matters for traders and economic policy watchers. These enthymemes are a rhetorical device at the heart of a persuasive speaking style that has helped catapult the billionaire to the White House.Trying to parse his words is one thing. Actually putting money to work quickly base on them brings far more risk than usual
column3: according to Brian Shapiro
column4: CEO of SPAG Funds
column5: a small global macro hedge fund manager based in New York. ""I won't react to it
column6: but the world will
column7: he said. ""I think people will have a heart attack if they react to every word.""""TRUMP LITE""

column1: Economic advisory firm Fathom Consulting dubbed the election outcome ""Trump Lite"": a world in which as President-elect he would be unwilling or unable to enact some of his more extreme policies such as building a wall at the Mexico border
column2: mass deportations of immigrants and wide-ranging protectionist measures.""Markets are waiting to see if we are going to have the campaign Trump who spoke in rhetoric
column3: or Trump the president who is going to be more pragmatic in his approach
column4: said Komal Sri-Kumar
column5: president of Sri-Kumar Global Strategies.Economists and fund managers
column6: as well as the Fed's policymakers
column7: are looking to see which issues Trump will prioritize. So far
column8: indications are he would pursue tax cuts
column10: and revamping President Barack Obama's Affordable Care Act
column11: dubbed Obamacare.Chicago Fed President Charles Evans
column12: speaking to reporters as Americans voted on Tuesday
column13: said he would try to figure out whether or not the new president's fiscal policies ""would be more simulative
column16: adding the level of market volatility would provide a clue.

column1: Trump has no defined economic team. It is unclear whether he will follow the lead of say Peter Navarro
column2: a professor at the University of California at Irvine
column3: whose studies suggest a tougher trade stance against China; or whether he could cleave to Wall Street allies such as former Goldman Sachs alumnus Steven Mnuchin
column4: who has been mooted by Trump as a potential Treasury Secretary.""Trump's fiscal plan as it stands is pretty vague and it doesn't add up
column5: said Paul Ashworth
column6: Toronto-based chief U.S. economist at Capital Economics. ""We expect some fiscal plan that will pursue the Republican agenda
column7: but it's likely to be much smaller in scale than the one originally envisaged by Trump."" While these policy questions are expected to persist even after Trump succeeds Obama in January
column8: ""the nature of the Trump cabinet appointments and the tone of their confirmation hearings will either ease or amplify the uncertainty premium in the markets
column10: U.S. chief economist at Mizuho.  Beyond Navarro and Mnuchin
column11: all eyes will be on whether many of the conservative economists
column12: like Columbia University business school dean Glenn Hubbard
column13: who abandoned Trump during a divisive campaign could ultimately return as advisors. Yet the reality-TV-host-turned-president-elect has struggled in the past to maintain the measured tone shown in his victory speech. During his campaign
column15: Trump appeared to suggest the United States could renegotiate its debts to obtain a better deal
column16: a comment he quickly rowed back upon. His past criticisms of Yellen as someone who should be ""ashamed"" of her policy actions
column17: and comments that she was keeping interest rates low for political reasons
column18: could roil markets if repeated during his wait to take office in January. ""He has managed to keep it under control some of the time
column19: Meltzer said. ""Whether he will be able to do that as president will very much determine whether he is successful."" (Additional reporting by Yashaswini Swamynathan and Lawrence Delevingne; editing by David Chance and Edward Tobin)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-protests-obama-idUSKBN1352F8	Obama to protesters: We're all Americans - White House	"
WASHINGTON U.S. President Barack Obama believes in the right of Americans to protest the election of Donald Trump in a non-violent manner
column2: but wants people to hear the message that ""we're Americans and patriots"" before Democrats and Republicans
column3: the White House said on Thursday.""It's important for us to remember
column4: a day or two after the election
column5: that we're Democrats and Republicans
column6: but we're Americans and patriots first

4	http://reuters.com/article/us-california-election-governor-idUSKBN1352F4	Former Los Angeles Mayor Villaraigosa enters California governor race	"

Former Los Angeles Mayor and former California State Assembly Speaker Antonio Villaraigosa on Thursday publicly launched his campaign to become the next governor of the country's most populous state.With a new campaign website
column2: the Democrat said his main focuses if elected would be investing in schools
column3: repairing infrastructure around the state and shoring up an ailing middle class.He said his campaign would stand in direct contrast to that of President-elect Donald Trump
column4: a Republican who campaigned heavily on building a wall between the United States and Mexico and deporting undocumented immigrants. Trump won the presidency in a surprise upset against Democrat Hillary Clinton earlier this week.""We are a state that builds bridges
column5: not walls. We are inclusive. We celebrate our diversity. And we welcome newcomers
column6: Villaraigosa said in a statement on his campaign website. ""We know the answer to fear is hope. The answer to division is unity.""

column1: Villaraigosa
column2: who was Los Angeles mayor from 2005 to 2013 and served as speaker of the California Assembly from 1998 to 2000
column3: is perhaps the state's highest-profile Latino leader.

column1: Villaraigosa in June said he had formed a political action committee and started raising money to help fight Trump's presidential campaign in key states with large Latino immigrant populations.California's Democratic Lieutenant Governor and former San Francisco Mayor Gavin Newsom said in early 2015 that he would also run for the state's top political position. The two are currently the leading entrants in the race to fill the seat of the popular Governor Jerry Brown
column2: who will be 81 when his term ends.

column1: (Reporting by Curtis Skinner in San Francisco; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"

6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-obamacare-analysis-idUSKBN135171	Trump promised to repeal Obamacare. Now what?	"
By Caroline Humer
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Republican President-elect Donald Trump vowed on the campaign trail to repeal Obamacare
column2: but making good on that promise may be easier said than done.President Barack Obama's 2010 national healthcare reform law extended medical insurance to 25 million more people by expanding the Medicaid plan for the poor and creating subsidized coverage for individuals.Republican lawmakers
column3: who have voted more than 50 times to repeal all or part of the law
column4: have begun pressing Trump to deliver. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said on Wednesday repealing Obamacare is a ""pretty high item on our agenda"" for the new Congress.But a complete repeal of Obama's Affordable Care Act may not be immediately in the cards
column5: as Republican lawmakers now hold 51 seats in the Senate at latest count
column6: well short of the 60 seats required to overturn it.Instead
column8: Trump could try to dismantle key elements through a process called budget reconciliation. That would allow him to eliminate funding for the income-based subsidies that make the new insurance plans affordable
column9: or cut the money providing expanded Medicaid benefits in 31 states.""Some of the policy experts on the Republican side would say tearing it up and starting over would be very disruptive
column11: director of health policy at the conservative Manhattan Institute.Parts of the law have been weakened through legal challenges. Several of the largest U.S. health insurers have pulled out of the exchanges for individual coverage after losing money on a sicker-than-expected group of patients. Consumers not eligible for government subsidies have seen premiums rise sharply
column12: including a projected average increase of 25 percent for 2017.Scrapping the law altogether without a clear plan for providing replacement coverage for so many people would be politically risky
column13: experts said. Trump also would face a tight deadline were he to try to dismantle the insurance exchanges by 2018; many state-based health insurance regulators require insurers to submit plans for the upcoming year by April or May - only a few months into a new administration.Trump also could seek changes to other provisions of the law
column14: such as a tax on medical device makers
column15: or the so-called ""Cadillac tax"" that is due to hit rich employer-based healthcare plans in 2020.

column1: However
column2: some elements could not be eliminated by depriving the law of funds. For instance
column3: the law prevents insurers from denying coverage to people based on their health or pricing insurance based on gender. Mandatory coverage of preventive benefits also would be unaffected - short of a complete repeal.It also is not clear if Trump would try to reverse the individual mandate
column4: which requires people to purchase health insurance or pay a penalty. The goal of the requirement was to broaden the pool of policyholders to include more healthy Americans.Aetna Chief Executive Officer Mark Bertolini said on Thursday at a New York Times Dealbook conference that some elements of the law are so popular that they are likely to continue
column5: even if there is something Trump calls ""repeal."" They include allowing young adults to stay on their parents' plans and people with health problems to buy insurance without paying more. Medicaid could continue to expand
column6: he said
column7: though with a different type of federal financing.SOWING CONFUSION OVER HEALTHCARE

column1: Trump's surprise victory over Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton rattled healthcare investors on Wednesday
column2: depressing shares in hospital operators and some insurers.Medicaid focused health insurer Molina Healthcare Inc. fell nearly 16 percent
column3: and hospital chain Tenet Healthcare Corp dropped 25 percent. Large insurers
column4: who have been losing money on the exchanges
column5: gained
column6: with Anthem Inc. up 1.5 percent.Enrollment opened on Nov. 1 for 2017 coverage and once those plans are purchased
column7: it would be legally difficult for Trump to cancel them before the one-year contracts run out
column8: said Molina Healthcare Chief Executive Officer Dr. Mario Molina.""Any changes they make will have to be on a prospective basis to begin in 2018
column9: Molina said.It's not clear what Trump's plan to replace Obamacare would look like. Options he raised on the campaign trail include replacing the Obamacare individual coverage with high-deductible healthcare plans
column10: and lumping the sickest people together into high-risk pools that are insured separately.

column1: I think there is going to be a lot of confusion and a lot of anxious people
column2: Molina said.Among the worries for some people covered under Obamacare is how long it will last.Before the law took effect
column3: Marc Dobin
column4: a 57-year old mediator and lawyer in Jupiter
column5: Florida
column6: said his insurer put a surcharge on his premium because he has heart stents. Under Obamacare
column7: insurers are barred from charging more for pre-existing conditions.""Imagine the disaster if
column11: the cost of premiums bolstered their support for Trump.Crista Simmons
column15: spends about a third of her gross income on premiums and medical care.""There are people who pay more in premiums than their mortgage
column17: additional reporting by Sue Horton; Editing by Michele Gershberg and Lisa Girion)"

NEW YORK Aetna Inc Chief Executive Officer Mark Bertolini said he expected some benefits of President Barack Obama's national healthcare reform law will stick under President-elect Donald Trump

LONDON U.S. President-elect Donald Trump invited Theresa May to visit him as soon as possible during their first telephone call since his election victory

9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-climatechange-idUSKBN1351QT	Trump could pull out of global climate accord in a year: lawyers	"
By Alister Doyle
| MARRAKESH
column2: Morocco

column1: MARRAKESH
column2: Morocco U.S. President-elect Donald Trump could use legal short-cuts to pull out of a global agreement for fighting climate change within a year
column3: keeping a campaign promise and by-passing a theoretical four-year wait
column4: lawyers say.Trump
column5: who has called global warming a hoax and said it was invented by the Chinese to undermine U.S. manufacturing
column6: has said he wants to cancel the 2015 Paris Agreement among almost 200 nations that entered into force on Nov. 4.The accord
column7: which seeks to phase out greenhouse gas emissions this century with a shift from fossil fuels
column8: says in its Article 28 that any country wanting to pull out after joining up has to wait four years.In theory
column9: the earliest date for withdrawal is Nov. 4
column11: around the time of the next U.S. presidential election.But Trump could pull out of the parent treaty of the Paris Agreement
column12: the 1992 U.N. Framework Convention on Climate Change with just a year's notice
column13: also voiding U.S. participation in the Paris Agreement
column14: U.N. legal experts say.That would be controversial
column15: partly because the Convention was signed by former Republican president George Bush in 1992 and approved by the U.S. Senate. It would also severely strain relations with many foreign nations.Meeting in Marrakesh
column17: for two weeks of talks to work out ways to implement pledges for action in the Paris Agreement
column18: many countries have reaffirmed support for the 195-nation accord since Trump's election victory on Tuesday.

column1: POLITICAL COSTS
If Trump withdraws from the Paris Agreement there would be a political cost. If he pulls out of the Convention the cost would be greater
column2: said Daniel Bodansky
column3: a professor of the Arizona State University Sandra Day O'Connor College of Law.""It would be going nuclear. It would signal that the United States has no interest in cooperating with other nations on climate change
column4: said Alden Meyer
column5: of the Union of Concerned Scientists.

column1: The Convention sets a goal of avoiding ""dangerous"" man-made damage to the climate to avert more heat waves
column2: downpours
column3: floods
column4: extinctions of animals and plants and rising sea levels. The Paris Agreement is much more explicit
column5: seeking to phase out net greenhouse gas emissions by the second half of the century and limit global warming to ""well below"" 2 degrees Celsius (3.6 Fahrenheit) above pre-industrial times.Trump wants to safeguard jobs in the U.S. coal and oil industries
column6: saying the Paris Agreement would undermine the U.S. economy. He said in May: ""We're going to cancel the Paris climate agreement.""But the accord has since entered into force in international law. As of Thursday it had been ratified by 103 nations representing 73 percent of greenhouse gas emissions.

column1: Trump could also pull out from Paris immediately if the Republican-controlled House and Senate passed a law asking him to do so
column2: Bodansky said. The Supreme Court had a tradition of upholding U.S. laws when they conflict with international law. ""If Trump acts with the approval of Congress there is no problem under U.S. law
column3: he said. There would be little recourse to challenge such a decision under international law - the Paris Agreement has no sanctions for non-compliance.Many delegates reckon Trump is likely to have other priorities
column4: from the economy to immigration. Trump may find it easier simply to oppose President Barack Obama's domestic plans to reduce U.S. emissions by between 26 and 28 percent below 2005 levels by 2025.The idea of the Paris Agreement's four-year wait is that ""it sets a legal trap
column5: said Tosi Mpanu Mpanu
column6: head of the 48-nation group of least developed nations. ""By the time Trump gets round to thinking about it we could have another president."" (Additional reporting by Valerie Volcovici in Washington; Editing by Gareth Jones)"
